title: China Economy - South China Morning Post
description: China economy news, including budget, the stock market and analysis.

items.title: ‘Bad policy’: China’s drone makers to shrug off US ban, analysts say
items.creator: Ji Siqi,Kandy Wong
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: ‘Bad policy’: China’s drone makers to shrug off US ban, analysts say
items.content:
Though it did not come as a surprise, the US’ formal ban on the sale of new drones produced by China marks a “milestone” in the two countries’ strategic competition and technological decoupling, analysts said, with their rivalry continuing across numerous fields despite the temporary trade truce agreed between their leaders in October.
Washington’s telecommunications regulator said on Monday that it is adding all foreign producers of drones and critical components – including those made by...

items.title: China vows city-specific fixes to clear housing glut, stabilise property sector
items.creator: Xinyi Wu
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: China vows city-specific fixes to clear housing glut, stabilise property sector
items.content:
China has pledged to empower local governments with city-specific measures to clear housing gluts and optimise supply next year, ramping up efforts to stabilise a real estate market that remains a persistent drag on the world’s second-largest economy.
“Municipal governments should fully utilise their autonomy in regulating the property market, adjusting and optimising policies as appropriate,” said Ni Hong, the minister of housing and urban-rural development, at a two-day work conference that...

items.title: As Germany’s trade deficit with China nears new high, analysts warn of backlash
items.creator: Xiaofei Xu
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: As Germany’s trade deficit with China nears new high, analysts warn of backlash
items.content:
Germany’s trade deficit with China is on track to hit a record high in 2025 amid shrinking demand for German goods – a trend that appears unlikely to be reversed in the short term and which could trigger a protectionist backlash, according to analysts.
China, already Germany’s biggest import partner, is set to increase its total exports to Germany by 7.2 per cent, with the value reaching €168 billion (US$197 billion), according to a forecast last week by Germany Trade and Invest (GTAI), an...

items.title: What China’s yuan internationalisation push looks like – and what may hold it back
items.creator: Sylvia Ma
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: What China’s yuan internationalisation push looks like – and what may hold it back
items.content:
The yuan has strengthened in recent months, with the offshore rate hitting its highest level against the US dollar in more than a year, fuelling forecasts that it could reach as high as 6.8 in 2026.
The currency’s international profile has also inched upwards as Beijing pushes for wider global use.
In this explainer, the Post reviews the yuan’s progress across several fronts, drawing on a recent analysis by Betty Wang, head of North Asia research at Oxford Economics.
How far has the yuan...

items.title: Hong Kong-listed Haichang Ocean Park’s boss detained in China amid shadow banking probe
items.creator: Daniel Ren
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: Hong Kong-listed Haichang Ocean Park’s boss detained in China amid shadow banking probe

images.alt: Yu Faxiang, the chairman of Hong Kong-listed Haichang Ocean Park, has been arrested on the mainland. Photo: Xinhua
images.title: Yu Faxiang, the chairman of Hong Kong-listed Haichang Ocean Park, has been arrested on the mainland. Photo: Xinhua

items.content:
Police in eastern China’s Zhejiang province have detained Yu Faxiang, the chairman of Hong Kong-listed Haichang Ocean Park Holdings, as authorities investigate alleged mismanagement following defaults on multibillion-yuan wealth products issued by a firm under his control.
It is the latest crackdown on mainland China’s shadow banking system, continuing years of government efforts to clean up the sector.
Police have imposed “criminal compulsory measures” against Yu and were conducting a probe...

items.title: Russian LNG shipments to China surge 143% in November, overtaking Australia
items.creator: Xinyi Wu,Mia Nurmamat
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: Russian LNG shipments to China surge 143% in November, overtaking Australia
items.content:
Russia’s shipments of liquefied natural gas (LNG) to China soared last month, consolidating Moscow’s role as the top energy supplier to the world’s second-largest economy even in the face of Western sanctions.
Imports of LNG from Russia surged 142.6 per cent, year on year, to 1.6 million tonnes, displacing Australia to become one of China’s top two biggest suppliers alongside Qatar last month, according to the latest customs data.
Russian LNG accounted for 23.5 per cent of China’s total...

items.title: China Vanke wins bondholders’ reprieve, averts default for now
items.creator: Bloomberg
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: China Vanke wins bondholders’ reprieve, averts default for now

images.alt: Potential buyers queue up for China Vanke’s Le Mont residential project in Tai Po at its sales office in Cheung Sha Wan on March 15, 2025. Photo: Nora Tam
images.title: Potential buyers queue up for China Vanke’s Le Mont residential project in Tai Po at its sales office in Cheung Sha Wan on March 15, 2025. Photo: Nora Tam

items.content:
China Vanke, once the mainland’s biggest developer before it succumbed to an unprecedented property crisis, won last-minute support from creditors to extend a bond grace period in a reprieve that helps it avoid default, at least for now.
Holders of Vanke’s 2 billion yuan (US$284 million) note voted in favour of a proposal to extend the grace period to January 28, according to a filing to Chinamoney.com on Monday. The company did not pay the security by its December 15 maturity, which left it in...

items.title: China’s record trade surplus could prompt protectionist response in 2026: report
items.creator: Kandy Wong
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: China’s record trade surplus could prompt protectionist response in 2026: report
items.content:
While China has already logged a record-breaking trade surplus in the first 11 months of 2025, that milestone could be a harbinger of more protectionist pushback, an American research firm said on Monday – a development that could complicate the country’s efforts to meet its economic growth target in 2026.
Though export performance remains the “most important” variable for China's real economic growth rate next year, trade measures adopted by other countries and weaker demand will also have an...

items.title: China to hide bad debt records for pandemic-hit borrowers who repay small loans
items.creator: Carol Yang,Ji Siqi
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: China to hide bad debt records for pandemic-hit borrowers who repay small loans
items.content:
China’s central bank has unveiled a credit-rehabilitation policy to help individuals who defaulted on small loans rebuild their financial standing – part of a broader push to bolster the economy and repair household balance sheets.
The People’s Bank of China said the measure targets borrowers with a single instance of overdue debt incurred between 2020 and 2025 and not exceeding 10,000 yuan (US$1,421). If the debt is fully repaid by March 31, the default record will be hidden from credit...

items.title: China slaps tariffs on EU cheese and cream amid trade row
items.creator: Xiaofei Xu,Ji Siqi
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: China slaps tariffs on EU cheese and cream amid trade row
items.content:
China has slapped provisional anti-subsidy fees of up to 42.7 per cent on European producers of certain dairy products, including various types of cheese and cream, Beijing’s Ministry of Commerce announced on Monday.
Chinese investigators made a “preliminary determination” – following a 16-month investigation – that the European Union provided “substantial subsidies” to the milk and dairy products industry “through programmes such as the common agricultural policy” and caused “material injury”...

items.title: Gold takes centre stage as Hong Kong hosts first committee to build commodities ecosystem
items.creator: Julie Zhang
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: Gold takes centre stage as Hong Kong hosts first committee to build commodities ecosystem
items.content:
Hong Kong is putting gold at the centre of its push to become a global commodities trading hub, with officials prioritising plans for an international gold trading centre alongside a broader strategy to expand the city’s role in physical trade, derivatives and logistics.
The government’s newly formed Commodity Strategy Committee held its first meeting on Monday under Financial Secretary Paul Chan Mo-po, as Hong Kong looked to build out a commodities ecosystem that would generate new growth...

items.title: China bans e-commerce platforms from forcing lowest prices or abusing algorithms

items.translated_title: China bans e-commerce platforms from forcing lowest prices or abusing algorithms

images.alt: The regulation also forbids platforms from setting different prices or charging standards for the same goods or services based on data like users’ willingness or ability to pay. Photo: Xinhua
images.title: The regulation also forbids platforms from setting different prices or charging standards for the same goods or services based on data like users’ willingness or ability to pay. Photo: Xinhua

items.content:
China has unveiled new rules to rein in aggressive pricing tactics by online platforms, prohibiting e-commerce operators from forcing merchants to offer discounts or setting different prices based on user demographics without consent.
The 29-article regulation – jointly issued over the weekend by the National Development and Reform Commission, State Administration for Market Regulation (SAMR), and Cyberspace Administration of China – lays out detailed compliance requirements that target several...

items.title: China’s rare earth magnet exports to EU jump nearly 60% as approvals take effect
items.creator: Kandy Wong,Mia Nurmamat
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: China’s rare earth magnet exports to EU jump nearly 60% as approvals take effect
items.content:
China’s exports of permanent magnets to the European Union saw a sharp rebound in November, as Beijing confirmed last week it has begun granting general licences with lengthier terms for overseas shipments of the materials, which contain valuable rare earth elements and are essential components in numerous hi-tech products.
Last month’s total export volume of the magnets to the EU increased 59.5 per cent year on year to 2,568.8 tonnes, according to figures released on Saturday by China’s General...

items.title: China eyes childcare overhaul with a law to boost births, fix demographic crisis
items.creator: Luna Sun
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: China eyes childcare overhaul with a law to boost births, fix demographic crisis
items.content:
China has taken a step towards regulating the childcare industry at the national level, drafting legislation to standardise services and lower costs as policymakers fight to reverse a demographic decline that could have long-term economic ramifications.
The draft Childcare Services Law was submitted on Monday to the Standing Committee of the National People’s Congress for review, according to Xinhua. The bill, comprising eight chapters and 76 articles, aims to establish a national legal...

items.title: Blackpink for Ayumi? Why China may reward South Korea’s soft stance amid Japan tensions
items.creator: Yeon Woo Lee
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: Blackpink for Ayumi? Why China may reward South Korea’s soft stance amid Japan tensions
items.content:
In a bid to overhaul their economic relationship, China and South Korea are reviving long-stalled trade talks, with an eye on moving beyond factory floors to target the lucrative services sector as geopolitical shifts redraw the region’s alliances.
The thaw follows a December 12 agreement between Minister of Commerce Wang Wentao and South Korean Minister of Trade, Industry and Energy Kim Jung-kwan to accelerate negotiations on the second phase of their free-trade agreement (FTA). The push aims...

items.title: From swoosh to local: Nike loses ground in China as domestic rivals start to sprint
items.creator: Zhu Wenqian
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: From swoosh to local: Nike loses ground in China as domestic rivals start to sprint
items.content:
Alex Chen – a Beijing office worker in his late 30s – used to buy his trainers the way plenty of Chinese millennials did: by the swoosh, the stripes and the logo.
As a teenager, he would hunt down Nike and Adidas basketball shoes, pulled in as much by the mythology as the materials. These days, he said, he shops differently.
“I have always been a huge basketball fan of Michael Jordan and Kobe Bryant,” he said. “Back then, I would specifically seek out Nike and Adidas basketball shoes – wearing a...

items.title: Chinese toymaker Pop Mart targets wider audience with Playground magazine, grow IP

items.translated_title: Chinese toymaker Pop Mart targets wider audience with Playground magazine, grow IP

images.alt: The new edition of Pop Mart’s biannual publication features Oscar-winning Malaysian actress Michelle Yeoh on its cover. Photo: Handout
images.title: The new edition of Pop Mart’s biannual publication features Oscar-winning Malaysian actress Michelle Yeoh on its cover. Photo: Handout

items.content:
Chinese toymaker Pop Mart, maker of the popular Labubu monster dolls, launched the second edition of its pop culture magazine as part of a strategy to widen its customer base and grow its intellectual property (IP) portfolio.
The company, which sells toys in blind boxes, started selling the Playground magazine for 39.9 yuan (US$5.7), with the theme of exploring the future.
“The magazine embodies emotional value and aligns with the younger generation’s desire for self expression,” Vicson Guevara,...

items.title: Arguing about China’s overcapacity overlooks its drive for clean energy
items.creator: Christine Loh
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: Arguing about China’s overcapacity overlooks its drive for clean energy
items.content:
China is often described today as having “overcapacity” in manufacturing. Its dominance in solar panels, batteries and wind equipment, for example, has left many observers baffled. How did a country once dismissed as undeveloped become, within a generation, so technologically developed that its success now unsettles global markets?
Part of the answer lies in how we frame China’s development. What is often described as excess capacity is better understood as the outcome of an energy-centred...

items.title: China eases visa rules for India, tapping into US$21.6 billion travel market
items.creator: Ralph Jennings
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: China eases visa rules for India, tapping into US$21.6 billion travel market
items.content:
Beijing and New Delhi have taken another step towards normalising economic ties after a five-year rift, as China moves to introduce a simplified visa process for Indian nationals that could help it tap India’s fast-growing travel market.
The Chinese embassy in New Delhi said earlier this month that Indian citizens would be able to apply for visas online from December 22, sparing them time-consuming initial in-person visits to the embassy or other consular offices in the country.
The move follows...

items.translated_title: Dior, Louis Vuitton ditch China’s malls for shopping streets to replicate Ginza’s charm

images.alt: Members of a Chinese tour group wait to cross a road in Tokyo’s Ginza shopping district. Photo: AFP
images.title: Members of a Chinese tour group wait to cross a road in Tokyo’s Ginza shopping district. Photo: AFP

items.content:
Stand-alone flagship stores with distinctive architectural facades, long prevalent in global metropolises like Tokyo, Seoul and New York, are gradually gaining traction in China, as the country’s retail landscape undergoes a broader shift from enclosed malls towards open-air and street-facing formats.
More luxury brands are setting up such flagships in places like Beijing’s Taikoo Li Sanlitun North, a trendy open-air commercial block developed and operated by Hong Kong’s Swire...
